audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a speaker indicating they knew they would be "limited" going into the production, explaining a "normal production was not going to happen." The speaker maintains a conversational tone. There is a single male speaker.

The clip begins with a male speaker presenting Simplisafe as a convenient home security solution, highlighting its online ordering and self-installation. Following this, another male voice enters, remarking on the creative process and logistical challenges of a prior endeavor. Transitioning to the next segment, hip hop music is introduced with a somewhat rebellious and energetic tone. At the same time, sounds suggestive of footsteps can be heard in the background.

The audio clip features multiple speakers identifying themselves. A male speaker says "My name is Wade Devers," mentioning his role as Creative Director at Electromatic for SimpliSafe. A second male speaker introduces himself as Aaron Lobell, founder and executive producer at Element Productions. Next, a male speaker identifies as Peter Davis, one of the three directors from Callier, and the actor who plays Robert Larson. Following him, another male speaker states "Hi, I'm Hunter Slessenger," also part of Callier. Lastly, a male speaker says "And I'm Eric Leplante" also one third of Callier. The clip ends with several of the male speakers collectively stating "We're all one third."

The audio clip starts with a male speaker preparing to delve into the topic of the Robert Larson character. He asks for an explanation of how long the character has been around. The male speaker proceeds to explain that Robert has been around for almost a year, conceiving against a brief. He then elaborates on the brief, asking to create a transactional brand-building idea, which the brief kind of begged for a spokesperson. He ponders creating a spokesperson that sticks in your brain and builds equity in the brand, as well as builds a bridge from that character to the brand. A second male speaker then appears, discussing Wade coming up with this concept and wanting to make something that resonated from a brand perspective and was able to be leveraged in conversion content that needed to go on social and digital.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing Robert Larson, mentioning, "Was there ever consideration of making him kind of more menacing?" He describes the character as a "friendly personification of of all that might go wrong, or kind of danger and fear." He is followed by a second male speaker who is talking about SimpliSafe and attributes of it being "pleasant to to work with." He mentions that it would be "incongruous to have a an overly menacing spokesperson." The third male speaker chimes in with, "We literally started casting for this character, and Peter, one of the directors, threw his hat in the ring." He continues, "Peter set the bar so high, we literally couldn't find anyone better than Peter for this role." Another male speaker follows up, saying, "Peter's a natural at his performance so that we didn't have to worry about that." He then adds, "There was no concern about performance really from the get-go, he just dove right into it."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker boasting about memorizing all lines without needing to consult the script. This transitions to another male speaker stating that the project started when they realized they would be confined for a while and started discussing possibilities. The first speaker then expresses how they wrote a script and passed it off. Subsequently, they went back and forth on how to execute the project. The speaker adds that their approach was to trust the team. Then another male speaker recalls being told if they had any ideas to elevate the project, to go for it. Another male speaker then adds that they were given the shooting board and asked to make something awesome, which they delivered. The clip ends with amusement.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker stating "Luckily," before asking a question about script preparations before a shoot. A second male speaker with a conversational tone responds by noting the advantage of wearing "a lot of hats," and prioritizing COVID safety protocols, mentioning mask-wearing and social distancing as challenging on-set adjustments. A third male speaker describes the project as "atypical" and intending to feel like Zoom or iPhone footage, without being overly polished, suggesting a character's quarantine communication. The second speaker elaborates that committing to shooting on iPhone led to a less art-directed approach compared to a larger crew setup. Finally, the third speaker remarks that this concept was a significant aspect of the project.

The clip starts with a male speaker suggesting that "Wade was really fine with the rawness of it".  Another male speaker then inquires about the first day of shooting, asking the speaker to describe the first few hours.  The tone of the conversation is casual.

The clip starts with a male speaker excitedly sharing how great it was for the three of them to be "back together to work on something," describing it as "putting on an old jacket." He adds that they could "just dive right into it." A second male speaker chimes in, sarcastically asking, "what it looks like is just you three walking around with an iPhone?" Throughout this conversation, there's a soft, rhythmic instrumental music playing in the background, creating a relaxed and slightly nostalgic mood.

The clip begins with two male voices discussing their on-set collaboration process. One voice explains how they value pre-planning and discussion. He mentions that the only gag they hadn't fully worked out was the "toilet paper gag," describing it as fun to improvise. The second voice chimes in, saying "throwing an iPhone in a cabinet" made the scene work. The audio then abruptly transitions to a male voice that sounds like a commercial speaker. This voice takes on an enthusiastic tone as he emphasizes the benefits of a security system, stating, "take it from an expert. Get Simply Safe and protect your home, your family, and anything else you need to keep a close eye on." A "doink" sound effect is heard.

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker discussing the importance of the "toilet paper reveal" and the comedic timing involved. He mentions that the team tested different approaches and shot multiple versions of the gag, emphasizing the benefits of being lean and working remotely, which allows for experimentation without slowing anyone down. He adds that the client felt comfortable and watched from their home using video village.

The audio clip features two male speakers discussing communication with a brand during a project, focusing on the level of trust given to the production team, mentioning nervousness about not being constantly on set, and expressing that this trust can lead to better work. The first speaker has a calmer, more conversational tone, while the second's is slightly more enthusiastic. There is no indication of music or background sounds.

The audio clip features a male speaker who is asked if "any other ideas came in a close second place". He replies with "No", stating "That's the only idea I had." His tone is conversational. He continues speaking about how part of the decision-making process involved "investigating how a production was going to work going forward if we couldn't produce a commercial under the normal production circumstances."

The audio begins with a male speaker inquiring about the reception of a particular advertisement. Another male voice responds with enthusiasm, stating that, from their perspective, it is "doing better than almost anything". The speaker continues on, emphasizing that it is great when "great creative executed in a way that's authentic to the brand" yields positive results. He concludes, noting that they "couldn't hope for a better outcome under worse circumstances". This is followed by the sound of a spray can.
